name: 2-amino-5-chloro-3-fluoropyridine
Reason: 2-Amino-5-chloro-3-fluoropyridine is a compound with several functional groups that can influence its melting point. The basic unit we can compare to is pyridine, which has a melting point of -42°C. The additional functional groups and structural features in 2-amino-5-chloro-3-fluoropyridine will affect its melting point: (1) The amino group (-NH2) can increase the melting point by about +20°C due to hydrogen bonding; (2) The halogen atoms (chlorine and fluorine) can increase the melting point by about +10°C each due to their electronegativity and the potential for weak dipole interactions; (3) The pyridine ring itself has a higher melting point than benzene due to its polar nature, which can add about +20°C. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
